original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified:
To understand how we developed the ability to use complex language, we need to look at how our brains are different from those of other animals. It’s not just about the size of the brain, but also what it can do and why it developed in that way. Unfortunately, we don’t have many physical clues to help us with this – objects left by our ancestors don’t tell us about their speech. However, we can see changes in the mouths, throats and tongues of early humans. Around 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists can only make educated guesses about how early humans communicated – whether they used simple sounds or not. 

**(Note: ‘evolutionary biologists’ are scientists who study how living things have changed over time. ‘ancestors’ are people who lived before us.)**

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified:
It’s not natural, but society that tells girls they are better at subjects like art and literature, and boys are better at maths and science. Also, young people don’t often see women working in science jobs. For example, in cartoons and stories, scientists, inventors, and astronauts are usually men. 

What’s more, some people unfortunately think scientists are strange, not very social, or work alone. These are not true – they are false ideas shown in the media. But these ideas might make girls think science isn’t a good career for them, and that they don’t fit in. 

If girls had more examples of successful women in science, they would feel more confident and like they belong in these subjects.
name: gemma-3-27b-it_descriptive_w_example

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The Scallion is a student newspaper that comes out every week. It’s given away for free in university buildings and about 10,000 students read it. Students write and make the newspaper completely by themselves.

A recent survey showed that students and staff really like the newspaper. They enjoy it for fun, to learn about different things, and to get experience for future jobs. However, printing the newspaper costs a lot of money. 

Also, not all students can easily get a copy because they have to go to the university to pick one up. Finally, many newspapers are thrown away on campus, which is bad for the environment.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified: I really agreed with a lot of what the speaker said. I honestly think that the more we use technology to connect with people, the more lonely we might feel. I don’t think this is a big problem for people my age, because we grew up without always having technology. We know how to be by ourselves, and we know that’s okay. But younger people, those under 20, are different. They spend so much time communicating with others that they don’t often feel alone. This means they might not learn how to enjoy being with themselves. Also, they are learning to talk by sending messages, which they can change before sending. This is different from talking to someone directly and quickly, which is a useful skill to learn.
name: gemma-3-27b-it_descriptive_w_example

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: Don’t always give negative feedback right after positive feedback. If you always say something good and then something bad, the good things might not seem important anymore. Make sure to sometimes give positive feedback without adding any criticism. Try not to always look for ways to improve things – just say what someone did well!
